Award.AbstractNarration:
A workshop "Height Zeta Functions" will take place April 28-30, 2017 at the University of Illinois at Chicago. The organizers of this workshop are Ramin Takloo-Bighash (University of Illinois at Chicago) and Yuri Tschinkel (NYU and Simons Foundation). The confirmed speakers are Margaret Bilu (Orsay), Tim Browning (Bristol), Alex Eskin (University of Chicago), Alex Gorodnik (Bristol), Brian Lehmann (Boston College), Daniel Loughran (Manchester), Lilian Matthiesen (KTH, Stockholm), Sho Tanimoto (Copenhagen), Yuri Tschinkel (NYU and Simons Foundation), Tony Varilly-Alvarado (Rice), and Takehiko Yasuda (Osaka). The website of the workshop is https://sites.google.com/site/rtakloo/2017-atkin-workshop

The theme of the workshop is exploring the connections between the arithmetic and geometry of algebraic varieties in the context of Manin's conjectures on the distribution of rational points. We hope that bringing together experts working in the area would create an environment in which to exchange ideas and to start new projects.Funding from the National Science Foundation makes it possible for junior researchers, graduate students, and other mathematicians without travel funds to attend this exciting workshop. This is an excellent opportunity for them to interact with expert and be inspired for further work. The lectures by invited speakers will happen on April 29 and 30. Select lectures will be videotaped, and will be made available on a website to make the lectures available to the mathematical community. The slides of talks will be made available on the same website.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary purpose of this grant was to fund the Atkin Memorial Lecture and Workshop at the University of Illinois at Chicago. A.O.L (Oliver) Atkin, a noted mathematician of international fame and professor emeritus at the University of Illinois at Chicago, died on December 23, 2008 at the age of 83. He made lasting contributions to the theory of numbers: the theory of modular forms (Atkin-Lehner operators, congruences, modular forms for non-congruences groups), theory of partitions, and cryptography (Schoof-Elkies-Atkin Algorithm), among others. He was also a pioneer of the use of computers in mathematics. He was born in England and worked at Bletchley Park in World War II. He completed his doctorate at Cambridge in 1952 under John Littlewood. He joined the faculty at the University of Illinois at Chicago in 1972. Atkin remained mathematically active until his death. The Atkin Memorial Lecture and Workshop is aimed at remembering Oliver's lasting contributions to the University of Illinois at Chicago and to number theory. This year's Atkin lecture was delivered by Yuri Tschinkel (NYU and Simons Foundation) on April 2008, 2017.  The speakers of the workshop on April 29 and 30 were: Margaret Bilu (Orsay), Tim Browning (Bristol), Alex Eskin (University of Chicago), Alex Gorodnik (Bristol), Brian Lehmann (Boston College), Daniel Loughran (Manchester), Lilian Matthiesen (KTH, Stockholm), Sho Tanimoto (Copenhagen), Tony Varilly-Alvarado (Rice), and Takehiko Yasuda (Osaka). The Atkin lecture was attended by about 130 participants. The weekend workshop was attended by about 40 mathematicians, many of whom were funded at least partially by the grant. 

Additionally the leftover money from the workshop, plus some additional funding from UIC, was used to organize a Pop-Up Conference in Number Theory at UIC, Nov 2-4, 2018. The speakers of the latter conference were 

Patrick Allen (UIUC), Elijah Allen (high school teacher, Baltimore), Jen Berg (Rice), Frank Calegari (University of Chicago),  Dylon Chow (UIC), Rachel Davis (Wisconsin), James Freitag (UIC), David Hansen (Notre Dame),  Andrei Jorza (Notre Dame), Daniel Le (Toronto), Eun-Hye Lee (UIC), Tong Liu (Purdue), Simon Marshall (Wisconsin), Vlad Matei (UC Irvine), Yong Suk Moon (Purdue), Kyle Pratt (UIUC), Karl Schaefer (University of Chicago), Shiang Tang (UIUC), and Darko Trifunovski (UIC)

 

Inellectual Merits: The Atkin workshop brought together leading experts in the theory of rational points on varieties with many rational points.  This is an extremely important area of research that has attracted a lot of attention in recent decades. The speakers discussed recent progress in the area, and introduced the participants to the most pressing problems in the field. 

Broader impact:  Funding from the NSF made it possible for mathematicians without funding, many of whom were women and underrepresented minorites, to attend the Atkin workshop. As for the Pop-Up Conference, 12 of the speakers were mathematicians without a tenure track positions (1 high school teacher, 6 postdocs, 5 graduate students). 

Because of the nature of the grant there were no other outcomes.
